conclusion: Two particles, A and B, start from rest at the same point and move in the same direction. A velocity-time graph is provided to find the ratio of their accelerations during acceleration phases.
Understanding a velocity-time graph: slope gives acceleration, area under curve gives displacement. Initial velocities are zero.
For particle A, accelerates from 0 to 2v₀ in time t₀, then decelerates to v₀ at 2t₀.
For particle B, starts from 0 and accelerates to v₀ at 4t₀, then decelerates to 0 at 6t₀.
Focus on acceleration phases: Particle A accelerates from 0 to 2v₀ from time 0 to t₀.
Particle B accelerates from 0 to v₀ from time 0 to 4t₀.
Calculate acceleration for particle A: a_A = (2v₀ - 0) / (t₀ - 0) = 2v₀/t₀.
Calculate acceleration for particle B: a_B = (v₀ - 0) / (4t₀ - 0) = v₀/4t₀.
Recheck calculations: a_A = 2v₀/t₀, a_B = v₀/4t₀, ratio is 8.
Consider slopes of velocity-time graphs: Particle A slope is 2v₀/t₀, Particle B slope is v₀/4t₀.
Ratio of slopes confirms ratio of accelerations is 8.
Red line in graph connects (0,0) to (t₀, 2v₀) for A and (0,0) to (4t₀, v₀) for B.
